nodes.bodyText:
We generally avoid UDF impl calling other UDF, to safeguard against incorrect error messages.
Also, datePlusIntervalDayToSecond and intervalDayToSecondPlusDate could produce different messages (when millis of day != 0), reversing param order.
You could address that by keeping arg validation inline and having a shared method for the actual math (or keeping everything inline (basically dropping this commit)).
I am leaning toward "validate inline and shared method for the math".
cc @electrum as this is a general comment about functions impls

We generally avoid UDF impl calling other UDF, to safeguard against incorrect error messages.

There's no hard and fast rule about that. I want to balance maintainability (i.e., having to fix bugs twice, change things twice, etc) with an explosion of methods (having 3 methods for everything seems overkill), especially when there's no validation involved. If there is, of course, it should be structured such that the message is appropriate for each implementation (e.g., see dateMinusIntervalDayToSecond). In this case, most methods don't do any validation.

Also, datePlusIntervalDayToSecond and intervalDayToSecondPlusDate could produce different messages (when millis of day != 0), reversing param order.

It doesn't and it shouldn't. DATE 'xxxx-xxx-xxx' + INTERVAL 'xxx' should not produce a different message than INTERVAL 'xxx' + DATE 'xxxx-xxx-xxx'. In both cases, an interval is being added to a date. The order of the operands is irrelevant.

I am leaning toward "validate inline and shared method for the math".

I agree, but only when it's deserved.
static createConstantAnalyzer

Removing isLegacyTimestamp check from here is not correct.
This code needs to verify the literal is correct (well formed valid value), and this depends on the isLegacyTimestamp + session zone.
For example 1970-01:01 00:30:00 is not a valid timestamp literal if legacy timestamp and session zone is Bahia_Banderas
Good catch. Too bad it wasn't caught by any tests

parse or convert?
(i am not sure about this code, but you are using convert* on two cases below)

BTW this looks like you're fixing a bug. Previously the code was using parseTimeLiteral which @return stack representation of legacy TIME or TIME WITH TIME ZONE type, depending on input, yet it was handling the return value as being of TIME type.
As such, this deserves a separate commit and a test.
I'm not really sure what the semantics would be. Let me look into it more closely.

BTW, there's no "convert" semantics for TIME. We either required a timezone (for TIME w/ TZ) or did not allow it (for TIME w/o TZ). We don't currently do the same thing as timestamps, where we allow optional TZ for TIMESTAMP w/ TZ.
I'll fix this in a separate commit (calling the appropriate parseXXX method), but I don't know how to add a test for this.
I don't know either, but i would start from io.prestosql.plugin.kafka.TestMinimalFunctionality#createMessages (but in TestKafkaIntegrationSmokeTest class)
rnn

Specify in the javadoc what happens when

timestamp is a gap in the provided zone (rejected or shifted)
value contains a zone specifier -- is it converted to provided zone with "same zone" or "same instant" semantics

and what happens if it cannot be
redundant else, below too
redundant else
This is a javadoc of something else, not this method.
The code here used to be known as parseTimestampWithTimeZone(TimeZoneKey timeZoneKey, String timestampWithTimeZone), but in the diff it appears as a new code.
Ah, that's because I inadvertently moved methods around. I'll restore the order to make the diff easier to review.

Fix legacy/new timestamp cast to json

This should probably be "Fix timestamp CAST to JSON in new semantics" or something, as you are not fixing anything in the legacy semantics (right?)
Yes
Same in RedisLoader (there is same code there)
I assume the changes in this class in fixup: Clarify parsing of timestamps and time types are just reorder.
Yes, it's easier to see once I squash the fixup commit.
to be clear: I am not questioning this. just letting know i passed over this "without deep read"
Yup, got it. Take a look now. I squashed the fixups, so now it should be clear what the actual changes are in that original commit.

Use a zone different from test jvm zone (to cover the fact that jvm zone doesn't impact this).
eg Vilnius
https://github.com/prestosql/presto/blob/ca878d471740c07155ea29fb74fe8be0ba855a68/presto-postgresql/src/test/java/io/prestosql/plugin/postgresql/TestPostgreSqlTypeMapping.java#L129-L130
(i used Bahia in my previous comment, because i remember when some gap is in Bahia, sorry for misguiding you)

+    {
+        Session session = testSessionBuilder()
+                .setSystemProperty("legacy_timestamp", "true")
+                .setTimeZoneKey(TimeZoneKey.getTimeZoneKey("America/Bahia_Banderas"))

nodes.bodyText: Does it matter? We rely on other tests to ensure that the session timezone is being respected. This is just making sure that "assuming session timezone is being respected => this timestamp is invalid". If the session timezone is not being respected and the test passes due to VM timezone, then that should trigger failures elsewhere.

nodes.bodyText:
It does matter. For example timestamp could be detected as invalid if it's invalid in JVM zone, but then could be shifted if it is invalid in the session zone.
Actually, i hope we also do have a test that parses timestamp being  a gap in JVM zone (but not in the session zone) and verifies it was succesful. We definitely do this in connector tests, but not sure if here.
